post_text:
I've seen a lot of concern about us losing the title "professional". The absolute lowest bar of acting like a professional is being a member of your professional organization. 

APTA is all over this fight and other fights like it every day, year after year. They protect and maintain our profession from constant attacks on our scope and our payment. I hope you'll join the 100,000 members of APTA who choose to support these constant battles that threaten our profession.

comments.text: I'm going to step away from this and let it bubble a little bit, but I'll be back with more responses. I would love to hear more from others who have had positive experiences in APTA. I see your thumbs up, but we need more vocal advocacy like this for our essential organization. Most people don't understand what a professional organization does, and I'm happy to try to pull back the curtain. A lot fo the work sounds boring, but it is literally the difference between PT existing and being swallowed up bit-by-bit by "body workers" and others. We would cease to exist shockingly fast without APTA.

All the pitchforks and torches came out to represent here, and I can't possibly find the time to respond to all of them. If you see that a bunch of people were clamoring for continued representaion as "professionals", and others could care less and have other priorities.... and then you multiply that by hundreds of issues with differing opinions across 300,000 licensed PTs, you start to see the complexity of APTA. I hope more of the PT profession can start to see APTA not as an optional organization, but one that fills hundreds of essential roles that no other organization can fill. Once we, as a profession, recognize that fact, we can all work together to make our profession and it's impact on people even better.

post_text: Asking for suggestions. I have an LLC and want to start marketing a mobile outpatient clinic with just me, a PT. I currently see mostly geriatric patients and post op joint replacements but also have my LSVT Big certification and really enjoy working with my current population. I have an opportunity to have a booth at a local wellness event and need some suggestions/recommendations on how to make my booth stick out. Besides business cards should I have give aways also? I was thinking of offering quick fall screenings and stuff. The event is 1/3/26 so coming up soon but was just offered the opportunity to have a booth at the event!

comments.text:
I do a lot of corporate events like this and the most popular giveaways Ive ever done were hyperice products (the giveaway depended on the size of the event). Iâ€™m also a sports med clinic so it fit the clinic brand. 

I also usually hire a massage therapist to give out free 5-10 minute chair massages. The person has to fill out a lead magnet before they are allowed to the massage this way I have their contact info to reach out to after the event.

post_text: What advice would you give to a therapist who wants to be uncaged?

comments.text: Answer three questions: WHY and WHY and WHAT.... Why do you want to be UNCAGED for yourself? What is in it for you and your family (or future family).  WHY does YOUR practice have to exist in the community?  WHAT is it that you do for people. Then..... BELIEVE in yourself. Understand what your PASSION is. Display ACTIVE PATIENCE.  Maintain your GRIT.  Finally, truly, save yourself time, money (in the long run), and a world of frustration by having a guide/mentor/coach who has done it to lead you.

Hire a business coach.  They help rocket your business forward faster and with less guesswork.  They have several proven processes because they've been there and have already helped others.
You're going to make your own mistakes no matter what, but you can avoid the ones they've already made. They know how to coach past them. 
David Bayliff , who runs this page has an incredible program. Free knowledge is great, but it only takes you so far.
You need to invest in your knowledge by hiring a coach. 
I am in my 3rd practice. A formal coaching group was the best investment I ever made.

post_text: I'm considering starting my own practice. Torn for many reasons. Unfortunately, small town and I would need to be in network with some insurances. comments.text:

We strictly cash-based, no insurance. My advice: hire a coach. You can do it!!!
If you are in network with an insurance company you canâ€™t charge people with that insurance for anything insurance covers.

post_text: I have a patient that requested medical records for disability. We provided these records and she wants to have a meeting to discuss some â€œinaccuraciesâ€ she sees in the record. I have explained that we can not/will not change the documentation. Am I required to meet with her? Or can I just ask her to email me a list of things she disagrees with and attach them to her medical record so that her concerns are documented?

comments.text: I believe a pt. Can request amendments for what they believe to be inaccuracies and you do have a certain time frame in which you need to respond. I would honestly call your malpractice and see what the procedure should be.
I recently reviewed some of my medical records and found inaccuracies.  They are entitled to request a change if they are inaccurate.

full_thread_text:
POST: I have a patient that requested medical records for disability. We provided these records and she wants to have a meeting to discuss some â€œinaccuraciesâ€ she sees in the record. I have explained that we can not/will not change the documentation. Am I required to meet with her? Or can I just ask her to email me a list of things she disagrees with and attach them to her medical record so that her concerns are documented?

COMMENT 1: I believe a pt. Can request amendments for what they believe to be inaccuracies and you do have a certain time frame in which you need to respond. I would honestly call your malpractice and see what the procedure should be.

COMMENT 2: I recently reviewed some of my medical records and found inaccuracies.  They are entitled to request a change if they are inaccurate.

post_text: Is Pickleball a good way to meet people and potential patients? Iâ€™m a beginner in the sport

comments.text: If your niche plays pickleball, yes. If they don't, no.

I definitely wouldnâ€™t use it solely to meet potential patients. Relationships that happen organically tend to lead to better connections in terms of patients. Iâ€™m a competitive powerlifter and I work out in a specialized gym for that, have for about 3 years now. Iâ€™ve never been shy about what I do for a living but Iâ€™ve never handed out a business card. So now my coach knows me and trusts me, and sends me his athletes when they need care. I never forced anything, and never intended to. It happened organically.

post_text: What are your top 2 interview questions when hiring a virtual assistant to make sure they are a good fit for your practice?

comments.text: Did you see the list in the drive?

Organization is key. I have them tell me specifics about how they stay organized. I will often give them a task as a test (paid for) and we'll use that to assess them.  It is usually a task that takes a good amount of organization. If they are also going to be customer facing and communicating with customers on a regular basis then I also test their their communication skills. Often I will give them a scenario and ask them to respond to a patient. It will be fake, but it lets me test what their email/phone skills are like and how they communicate and how they come off.  It also allows me to test how they do with problem solving given limited instructions.  These tasks are also timed tasks so it lets me assess their ability to meet deadlines.

full_thread_text:
POST: What are your top 2 interview questions when hiring a virtual assistant to make sure they are a good fit for your practice?

COMMENT 1: Did you see the list in the drive?

COMMENT 2: Organization is key. I have them tell me specifics about how they stay organized. I will often give them a task as a test (paid for) and we'll use that to assess them.  It is usually a task that takes a good amount of organization. If they are also going to be customer facing and communicating with customers on a regular basis then I also test their their communication skills. Often I will give them a scenario and ask them to respond to a patient. It will be fake, but it lets me test what their email/phone skills are like and how they communicate and how they come off.  It also allows me to test how they do with problem solving given limited instructions.  These tasks are also timed tasks so it lets me assess their ability to meet deadlines.

post_text: How did I miss this this week??? Who went? What was the outcome?? Why wasnâ€™t this all over the place?? Not only did I not see it all over I didnâ€™t see it all ALL ANYWHERE. Link below ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¼

comments.text: I went.  Got multiple emails about it ahead of time....starting in Jan/Feb timeframe I believe.  About 1/4 of the PTs there were private practice owners.  You're split up by states and you schedule meetings ahead of time with your senators and local districts.  I also went 5 years ago.  It's impossible for a lot of PTs to go because you absolutely cannot put 20+ PTs in a meeting room with a congressman...they physically wouldn't all fit.  BUT that isn't to say that when your representatives are back home and away from DC that you meet up with them and advocate for what you want to see change.  That really is the best way and I've done that many times here.
Same! Saw the After photos.

Other than the obvious! and telling â€œcagedâ€ clinicians to become â€œuncagedâ€ how can we help our fellow caged clinicians, who need a W2 job for whatever reasons?

How can we help those still in SNFs or contract rehab Co. advocate for a new healthcare bill to prevent 100% productivity, groups and concurrents to be forced upon them, to the point at which we have â€œTherapist & Me: Senior Nap Time ğŸ˜´ groupsâ€ being paid for by Medicare! Or therapist working off the clock in drovesâ€¦

Any verbiage I think of will also hurt us, who can ETHICALLY run well oiled, outcome producing, high level, outpatient groups and concurrentsâ€¦

There has to be come creative way to word this bill I am envisioning to put the CARE back in SNF healthcare without hurting my fellow â€œuncagedâ€ clinicians private practices.

comments.text: I do have an advocacy group but many in there are in the other side of the business and would not understand this question

What about a policy that states 

â€œ
If â€¦clinician works within the same facility that has the at least 1 of the following 3 professionals also working or contracted there:
1. Doctors
2. Nurses
3. CNAs
Or 
Ifâ€¦the clinician has any Med A patients on their caseload that day

Thenâ€¦the CTC, SNF, or ALF shall never do the following unethical things:
1. Demand that the clinicians productivity will be above 75% billable time that day
2. Dictate which clients are placed in a group
3. Threaten the clinician with an action plan or job termination for not grouping per scheduled list or not going above 75%

This will ensure that the following will occur:
1. quality and individualized patient care 
2. non-billable discussions with the IDT
3. medically necessary groups
4. working ON the clock

I would need something to record video and preferably also my mic'd audio. (I do not have a mic yet.)

On the editing side, adjusting my recorded audio to a desirable volume should be pretty simple, right? ğŸ˜¬ We meet in a gymnasium (echo), I talk really loud so everyone can hear me, and I play music through a Bluetooth speaker.

comments.text: Go to my GeriHab Physical Therapy and Wellness . I sometimes steam our group exercise. Don't make it complicated . I use my phone and a lapel mic

I use the free version of capcut to edit video clips for Instagram. I haven't recorded large groups and I usually edit out my voice bcuz I don't have a mic. I just use my phone and a tripod to hold my phone. Capcut is great and easy and if you pay for premium you can do more edits to the audio quality. You can also take a video and record the audio separately for better quality and then put them together thru that program

post_text: Anyone have any good advice/tips for making posts to local community Facebook pages? I'm looking to take my Mobile Med B side hustle to full time, trying to get more community outreach. I've gotten a good amount of likes on my posts, but it's not converting at the rate I'd like to getting more patients. Thanks!

comments.text:
Local groups are great for building "famousity"! So be present in the groups. A lot.

Respond to people's posts, even if it has nothing to do with you.

Recommend services that you don't offer, but trust and feel confident recommending.

Connect with the other regular posters who share part of your vision; become their friend.

Pay attention to the most frequently asked questions that are relevant to you -- the questions can become content for you (digital or workshops or both), and the people asking can become people you offer free resources and information to, until they're ready to have you solve a problem they have.

If there's a "small business posting" day, use it.

If there are networking events advertised, try them.

I posted a video of me introducing myself and my new business in a local FB group when I was just starting and it actually worked well! I think I got at least like 8-10 people contact me and 3-4 new patients schedule, which felt like a win to me!

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 1: Local groups are great for building "famousity"! So be present in the groups. A lot.

Respond to people's posts, even if it has nothing to do with you.

Recommend services that you don't offer, but trust and feel confident recommending.

If there's a "small business posting" day, use it.

If there are networking events advertised, try them.

post_text: PTs- thoughts on becoming an APTA member? I've heard mixed thoughts and wondering if it worth it. If so, what other dues (chapters) did feel was worth paying for in addition to membership and your state chapter?

comments.text: I love being a member. I'm headed to Boston on Wednesday for Combined Section Meeting, a gathering of over 15,000 PTs/PTAs students. The educational content, resources, CEUs is top notch and being a member and getting involved in the Academy of APTA Home Health has introduced me to tons of clinicians across the country, given me opportunities to represent home/mobile based clinicians on CPG projects, present content on part B at home to the Neuro section. I could go on and on. It is a seriously small percentage of our profession that belong to the APTA compared to other health care professions. I encourage everyone to get involved and be the difference you want to see.

No way. My job paid all membership dues so I became a member and part of several sections and stayed a member for 6 years and got nothing out of it more than a magazine and the occasional sticker. Not worth it.

full_thread_text:
POST: PTs- thoughts on becoming an APTA member? I've heard mixed thoughts and wondering if it worth it. If so, what other dues (chapters) did feel was worth paying for in addition to membership and your state chapter?

COMMENT 1: I love being a member. I'm headed to Boston on Wednesday for Combined Section Meeting, a gathering of over 15,000 PTs/PTAs students. The educational content, resources, CEUs is top notch and being a member and getting involved in the Academy of APTA Home Health has introduced me to tons of clinicians across the country, given me opportunities to represent home/mobile based clinicians on CPG projects, present content on part B at home to the Neuro section. I could go on and on. It is a seriously small percentage of our profession that belong to the APTA compared to other health care professions. I encourage everyone to get involved and be the difference you want to see.

COMMENT 2: No way. My job paid all membership dues so I became a member and part of several sections and stayed a member for 6 years and got nothing out of it more than a magazine and the occasional sticker. Not worth it.

post_text:
Hi all, this is the first time I am completing a Medicare REVALIDATION and they are requesting
" Copy of an organizational structure diagram/flowchart"
The provider must submit an organizational structure diagram/flowchart identifying all of the entities listed and their relationships with the provider and each other.....
What is that?

comments.text:
#Compliance #Revalidation - Is this an individual revalidation, or a group revalidation? Per CMS checklist this diagram/flowchart only required for the Group/organizational revalidation. GototheSource

A flowchart is an org chart consistent with documentation provided/updated in Section 5.

## Plans succeed with many advisors...

**Looking to have your plans succeed in 2024? **

**It would be wise to get around many advisors.**

Many advisory groups have been started by the APTA and other organizations, but to be honest, they seem to miss the mark of what a practice owner actually needs.

That is why we created Success Council's - A council of 6-8 practice owners across the country that are in similar revenue range and size to grow in connection and trust with. We say #ironsharpensiron, but the question is - Are you putting yourself around iron?

When you start to run a business, you start to quickly realize that the game that you are playing is vastly different than most people around you, and most of the time...family and friends simply can't relate.

This can be frustrating and isolating. We have created the community where you can grow your own personal board of directors as you grow your company. Other entrepreneurs that you can rely upon for counsel, accountability, collaboration, and support.

If you are interested, comment "Success Council" below! And then, we will get you all of the details.

When you start to run a business, you start to quickly realize that the game that you are playing is vastly different than most people around you, and most of the time...family and friends simply can't relate.

This can be frustrating and isolating. We have created the community where you can grow your own personal board of directors as you grow your company. Other entrepreneurs that you can rely upon for counsel, accountability, collaboration, and support.

If you are interested, comment "Success Council" below and we will get you all of the details!

COMMENT 1: Success council

post_text:
Hello!

I'd love your input. I launched my practice five months ago, but I'm struggling to gain traction. I've partnered with a marketer who holds an extensive lead list in my local area, boasting 2,000-3,000 potential leads. He sends out emails for me 1-2 times a week, featuring a short video that I create. We meet weekly to brainstorm video ideas, and he's also working on getting me into gyms for workshops. His fee is $750/month and he covers all the operational costs. I'm planning to collaborate for three months to assess the return on investment. Do you believe his services justify the cost? As someone new to marketing, I'd greatly appreciate your feedback. 

Thank you so much for your input

comments.text: What type of cash practice.. what population?

Are you out in the community and networking? Have you met with your local direct care physicians? Reached out to nurse case managers, ones in private practice and within in hospital systems? Visited your local senior centers and give talks about your services, disease process, fall prevention ect.. whatever your target population go to where they are and be visible. I'm scheduled to talk to a local Parkinsons support group and a dementia caregivers group in January- emailed them myself, introducing myself and asking to speak on the topic. You have to put yourself out there!

post_text: Looking to start treating people in groups for exercise/ strength/ balance and endurance training. How would I bill this ? How many clients can be in group?

comments.text:
Would definitely approach this from a wellness side rather than PT.

If they're all in PT for the same things and you want to do group therapy to save time, fine, but the reimbursement is not good. 

If they're all just needing generic/community-accessible physical activity, then do that as a group exercise class instead.
Medicare reimburses terribly for group therapy if itâ€™s therapeutic. If itâ€™s wellness then it would be cash pay. I have integrated this into my practice. Let me know if you have any questions

full_thread_text:
POST: Looking to start treating people in groups for exercise/ strength/ balance and endurance training. How would I bill this ? How many clients can be in group?

COMMENT 1: Would definitely approach this from a wellness side rather than PT.

If they're all in PT for the same things and you want to do group therapy to save time, fine, but the reimbursement is not good. 

If they're all just needing generic/community-accessible physical activity, then do that as a group exercise class instead.

COMMENT 2: Medicare reimburses terribly for group therapy if itâ€™s therapeutic. If itâ€™s wellness then it would be cash pay. I have integrated this into my practice. Let me know if you have any questions

Tulsi

comments.text: Iâ€™m new as well and from  what I hear is that we need patience.  (And patients!)

Keep going! Iâ€™m into my 4th month and finally getting traction. Connect with local gyms (Pilates, yoga, where moms usually hang out since youâ€™re pelvic floor), networking groups, set up tabling, etc. use your time wisely and give yourself grace. What you put in is what youâ€™re going to get. Educate yourself in sales so you know what to say when you do have a prospect/lead in front of you. Best of luck!

Two of the members of the Uncaged Clinician Facebook Group have been selected as finalists for the South By Southwest Education Conference in Austin, TX in March of 2024!

Your Fearless Leader..."The Captain"...@David Bayliff and "The Professor of Profit" Dr F Scott Feill have proposed a Podcast Style Live Presentation entitled: ***Why Zone of Genius is Imperative Towards Establishing Expertise***

Starting TODAY, **Wednesday, August 16**, the greater online community is invited to vote and share their input on all of the session ideas through **Sunday, August 20**. 

The community's input will amount to 30% of the total score for the proposals. The proposals will also be evaluated by the SXSW EDU Advisory Board (40%) and SXSW EDU staff (30%) during this time.

Anyone with internet access can cast a single vote for as many proposals as they would like upon creating a [PanelPicker account](https://urldefense.com/v3/__https:/explore.sxsw.com/e3t/Ctc/OL*113/c3yrK04/VW1zxV8mLJPBW7BPZKw3cf62YW5l3Nw351ZSRQN1vWRr-3qgyTW6N1vHY6lZ3mKVd3yLH1c212DW8D0PJ_1VpbsKW5WY50V6w-J5ZW56P3Gf91LnWDW3J15Zp3y0fhBN2ST7JVPvdkxV8MLbr11gg98W2x4wh23wFZydW267tWS5TTvywW48dD8y1GKlg5W8xZ6SY3VPhqmW4P8GQH6fMbXBW8G-KTk6B62jyW8sy6BB7D2LZ0W7Yy8YD87Gtj9W1FVgPN65CdsDW4R_mLP3YH7YtW4hRHCZ4tG1lcW2X1-2l5YT6dCW7WRcLF1BcZstW6BqyGf3QW1wPW3f5_bn1ssNLBf5HJx6-04__;Kw!!L1pk_x_9Nw!BWP5XneAvzo7H5fUMYsukLtbG_HhZ5i64O4rMtJXlxlNGLCbhkaaZiOYoObBUd_deLNK_yGsuaKStwr9qQdS$). Has anyone done coaching?
 I have a client that reached out to me; I  could facilitate from a coaching aspect; but afraid to cross boundaries...but I  see coaches recommend things that a professional has done and recommended. This line is very blurry to me. Can y'all help me clarify, What the difference is between a coach and a therapist...(I know in my practice but what the view from the outside world and if you do both how do you differentiate.??? Thanks!

comments.text: Really look at the difference between therapeutic exercise and general exerciseâ€¦. There is very little to no difference. Itâ€™s all on a spectrum. I think itâ€™s a shame that therapists get overshadowed by trainers but itâ€™s because we as a profession lack confidence. You can and should coach. But also know school probably didnâ€™t prepare you for program design. Joe Camoratto covers that pretty well too.

If a strength coach or personal trainer could make the program youâ€™re making, itâ€™s not skilled. Iâ€™ve coached close to 100 athletes remotely and have no formal personal training or strength coaching education outside of self education

full_thread_text:
POST: Has anyone done coaching?
 I have a client that reached out to me; I  could facilitate from a coaching aspect; but afraid to cross boundaries...but I  see coaches recommend things that a professional has done and recommended. This line is very blurry to me. Can y'all help me clarify, What the difference is between a coach and a therapist...(I know in my practice but what the view from the outside world and if you do both how do you differentiate.??? Thanks!

COMMENT 1: Really look at the difference between therapeutic exercise and general exerciseâ€¦. There is very little to no difference. Itâ€™s all on a spectrum. I think itâ€™s a shame that therapists get overshadowed by trainers but itâ€™s because we as a profession lack confidence. You can and should coach. But also know school probably didnâ€™t prepare you for program design. Joe Camoratto covers that pretty well too.

COMMENT 2: If a strength coach or personal trainer could make the program youâ€™re making, itâ€™s not skilled. Iâ€™ve coached close to 100 athletes remotely and have no formal personal training or strength coaching education outside of self education

post_text: I am a mobile LLC PT business and Iâ€™m the only provider.  For becoming in network with Tricare, which application do I do?

comments.text:
They do not accept the group one for physical therapists if it is still on paper. I did that one and got a call 3 months later that itâ€™s not acceptable and had to fill out the individual one. 

I asked why it was still up if they donâ€™t take it and why they TOLD me to fill it out andâ€¦ just a big shrug of the shoulders from them.
I would do the group so as you grow its covered. They likely also want you to do the individual.

full_thread_text:
POST: I am a mobile LLC PT business and Iâ€™m the only provider.  For becoming in network with Tricare, which application do I do?

COMMENT 1: They do not accept the group one for physical therapists if it is still on paper. I did that one and got a call 3 months later that itâ€™s not acceptable and had to fill out the individual one. 

I asked why it was still up if they donâ€™t take it and why they TOLD me to fill it out andâ€¦ just a big shrug of the shoulders from them.

COMMENT 2: I would do the group so as you grow its covered. They likely also want you to do the individual.

comments.text: Where are you in Indiana?

1. Check that your insurance covers you wherever you are

post_text:
MAJOR ANNOUNCEMENT. 

TLDR: register for the Uncaged Clinician Community and App launch party using the link in the comments! 

Honestly this is the biggest thing we've ever done at Uncaged Clinician and our team is so excited to start sharing it with you! 

We're in a unique position that we've been asked to leverage for the betterment of PTs, OTs, SLPs, Chiros, Mental Health Providers and more. At first, Josh Payne, David Bayliff and myself wanted to "stay in our lane" and focus on coaching and mentorship but this changes NOW. 

This group has evolved and grown through the last several years and although the growth is exciting, it's also very sad that the level of satisfaction and fulfillment in healthcare seems to be plummeting. 

We all have our thoughts on why this is the case but we're all fighting in isolation and lack a common voice and space for grassroots change and growth. 

Will we "fix" healthcare in the US? probably not, but the goal that we have is to unify the voices of PTs, OTs, SLPs, and more and stop the infighting that keeps us from collective growth. 

In order to bring us more together, we're launching a community platform and app that focuses on clinical and business development, resourcing clinicians, mentorship, collaboration, accountability, and community and we want YOU to be a part of it. 

Yes this will take time and yes there will be some kinks that need to be ironed out but we need a group of clinicians who are willing to be trailblazers with us to help move this mission forward. 

All that being said, we are hosting an EXCLUSIVE training and launch party on March 22nd at 8:00 pm eastern to teach you, motivate you, and show you what we've been working on. 

Spaces in the training are limited and spaces for the trailblazers on the app are going to be limited as we continue to grow and launch this to more and more people! 

Register using the link below and give this post some love because we want to make sure everyone in this group knows that we're on a mission to unify voices in our fields and reinvigorate the passion that you once had for loving, serving, caring, and leading others in healthcare.

comments.text: So pumped!! This is going to change the game for our profession and healthcare as a whole
Letâ€™s GO Uncaged Clinicians!! Want to bring our profession together in a really unique way that hasnâ€™t been done yet? We believe this is the beginning of so much! Get signed up â¬†ï¸

Do you identify as a Neuro PT and practice in the U.S.? If so, please consider completing this survey on Neuro PT leadership practices:

[https://samuelmerritt.az1.qualtrics.com/.../SV...](https://samuelmerritt.az1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_djtgBvo56bSr0Bo?fbclid=IwAR2R7LGL9b8o9EUKBQXgDpWgEKrcrVqk3MZTD6krAD-ZCn3ayT-eiqx4_aA)

Additionally, if you practice in a clinic that includes or exclusively provides health promotion & wellness/fitness programing for people with neurologic diagnoses, this research also seeks to describe these program characteristics so that we can collaborate in bridging the gap between rehab and wellness/fitness for people with neurologic disability. If we don't know what's out there, we can't connect and work together to meet the needs of our patients. Thank you so much, and please share with a friend! Want to know more, catch me on the "I love neuro" podcast next week, or message me to connect at CSM! (photo cred: [nchpad.org](http://nchpad.org/?fbclid=IwAR31U_WTV0UF2cdfTmlVTMJAri_Ciwv2shwlDz6u-vvDFp9wPaT0OnUlgFc))

post_text: Any PTs here do coaching for runners? I have a cash based mobile PT side gig and have been able to get well entrenched in our running community and started coaching some athletes on a month by month subscription basis and wondering if anybody else more experience in this area. Looking for any information/strategies people have taken in this area combining PT/coaching.  Thank you ğŸ™

comments.text: Initially I also focus on injury prevention just as Denise Fontana Smith described.  Also,  patientâ€™s will transition to my coaching program & technique training during the latter phases of rehab (if their goal is to return to running).  I spend 1-2 days/week coaching and programming for folks who are preparing for a race or in the military. Another strategy is to do some small group sessions for runners who have similar goals or experience level. I donâ€™t do that anymore, but it seemed to work well.  Let me know if you have any specific questions.

We do along with running technique training.  The coaching field is crowded so we focus more on injuries (treatment and prevention) and design programs around that. Smith Physical Therapy and Running Academy

Hello, 
 Is there anybody with a mobile business that has contracted or partnered with an assistive living facility of some kind where you provide group exercise classes for the facility? I'm looking into trying something like this and want some insight from people who have experience. TIA

comments.text: I have some experience with this. It was a great set up, but ultimately the ALF  eventually hired an employee to lead classes as a way to save money. Happy to answer any questions if youâ€™d like to DM me.

I am contracted with a group of homes with adults with developmental ï¿¼ disabilities   Homes are group based on gender and level of disability. I have seen it all from humerus fracture from ï¿¼ a fall during the Highland Park, Fourth of July shootings when the house went on lockdown too simple things like general hypotonia and difficulty ambulating or stair negotiation. The medical Director of these homes is very thankful. She does not have to fill out all of the paperwork for the residence being homebound and likes that I can provide more frequent treatment.

post_text:
I needed to hear this because I have had these thoughts recently. Hope this helps some of you in the trenches with me. 

We all have bad days, weeks or monthsâ€¦. It is the nature of the beast of being a solopreneur and biz owner. Hell itâ€™s the nature of life. But when is it good to give up??

I heard this from Jake Thompson today on one of his old podcasts.  â€œNever give up on a bad day. Itâ€™s easy to want to quit on our dreams and desires when we have a bad day, because everything in our perspective makes it seem like we should. But if you have a good day and you still want to quit, then maybe strongly consider it.â€  If you can have a good day and you still donâ€™t feel like this is for you, donâ€™t feel bad. Realize that you have the gumption to look at yourself in the face and know that this road isnâ€™t for you. And thatâ€™s ok. But donâ€™t give up just because you had a rough/bad day. They are going to happenâ€¦

Uncaged clinicians, donâ€™t give up on your dream because of a rough patch. We all have them, reach out and talk to someone: a mentor, accountability partner, a friend. They can help you through. If after a good day, you still want to quit, then realize this may not be for you, then find a new dream.  And crush that!!  Pivoting is never a bad thing!

comments.text: Always good to hear this. Definitely in the crossroads of decisions
Love it. Thank you for sharing.

I heard this from Jake Thompson today on one of his old podcasts.  â€œNever give up on a bad day. Itâ€™s easy to want to quit on our dreams and desires when we have a bad day, because everything in our perspective makes it seem like we should. But if you have a good day and you still want to quit, then maybe strongly consider it.â€  If you can have a good day and you still donâ€™t feel like this is for you, donâ€™t feel bad. Realize that you have the gumption to look at yourself in the face and know that this road isnâ€™t for you. And thatâ€™s ok. But donâ€™t give up just because you had a rough/bad day. They are going to happenâ€¦

Uncaged clinicians, donâ€™t give up on your dream because of a rough patch. We all have them, reach out and talk to someone: a mentor, accountability partner, a friend. They can help you through. If after a good day, you still want to quit, then realize this may not be for you, then find a new dream.  And crush that!!  Pivoting is never a bad thing!

COMMENT 1: Always good to hear this. Definitely in the crossroads of decisions

COMMENT 2: Love it. Thank you for sharing.

post_text: Anyone here got some experience with the Uncaged Clinician Pathway program?

comments.text: I am a fairly new member and am glad I signed up.  I have had a lot of things going on and haven't been able to really dive full speed into the program but will have the chance to do so this month, and I am super excited.  My goal is to open for business in January, and I would like to not have to learn everything the hard way.  I know how to be a PT, but I don't know how to start and run a business - that's why I signed up for the coaching program.  So far, the one-on-one coaching calls have been fantastic.  I've also learned and gotten some ideas from the bi-monthly group calls even though we are not all at the same point in our businesses.

I went through the program in the summer of 2020. I highly recommend the coaching program, worth the investment and helps you get organized as you start your business especially with building relationships and your messaging. The coaches really want the best for you and push you to unlock your potential.

Topics vary month to month, but I believe you would find them all of interest and benefit to you.  You DO NOT have to be a member of the APTA and/or CO APTA to participate. post_text:
ISOLATION: The second great killer of your business 

You weren't meant to do THIS alone and by "THIS" I don't just mean business. 

Scenario 1: I hate when people outside a select few friends ask me how business is going. It doesn't seem fair to have to communicate something as complicated as an entrepreneur's emotions. It's great, it's terrible, it's ok, it's frustrating, it's exhilarating, it's everything at the same time. So most of the time people ask I simply say "it's going well" and leave it at that. 

The problem with this? It puts you on an island feeling that no one can possibly understand or know what you're going through. 

Scenario 2: there's something that's been engrained in you from your childhood- using other people to help you is cheating, you need to do it on your own, group projects are awful, and if you collaborate with someone it cheapens what you're accomplishing. 

All of these things have gone through my head from time to time. I want to prove to everyone that I can do it on my own and don't need to rely on support or help from outsiders. "I didn't borrow money from a wealthy family member to get started." "I'm the reason people are coming to my practice." "I'm going to see how far I can get it on my own before asking for help." 

Phrases like this are so prevalent in our culture. 

Both of these scenarios create a pattern of isolation that make us susceptible to a number of problems. We burn out because we can't sustain the level of energy we're putting in. We quit because there's no accountability to push through challenges. We feel depressed because we're alone. 

At the very least you don't need to do this alone but the honest truth is that doing this alone is irresponsible. Don't let yourself become susceptible to isolation. Surround yourself with community to support you and allow you to have the greatest opportunity to have true success.

comments.text: Good timing. Rough day!

Perfect timing for this!  Ty! 
Iâ€™m a bit tired of the island lately â¤ï¸

post_text:
For those of you who don't know me, yet - I am Kalyca! I work closely with Josh Payne, David Bayliff, and Kevin DeGroot at Uncaged Clinician. 

Over the past two weeks I've had the incredible honor of sitting in on our bi-annual Board Meeting Calls. These are something we do twice a year with each one of our Mastermind Students. 
The goal of these calls is to check-in, vision-cast, and better understand how we can truly show-up and support each individual business owner. 

I recognized something REALLY awesome yesterday that I wanted to share with the whole group...

If you know Josh, David, and Kevin ... you probably already admire them for their modesty and humility. All three of them often say the phrase, "it's not about me"... in reference to how IT IS all about each of our coaching students and IT IS about how we can serve them and care for them to the best of our ability.

Since they would never say this about themselves... I'll open up my loud mouth and share what I've witnessed. Watching them show up over and over and over again for every single one of our students is nothing short of REMARKABLE. 

They are so uniquely talented in recognizing what each person needs, articulating it in a supportive way, and truly serving from their heart so that each person can leave the call with their cup filled in just the right way. The manner through which they intuit this is actually pretty mind blowing to witness...

Support can come in many forms ... sometimes a gentle push, a shoulder to literally cry on, or an accountability partner. These guys always seem to know exactly what each person needs. 
Witnessing this gift in each of them makes me feel energized by how much they are living into their purpose. 

If ever you find yourself wishing you had this level of support... you should certainly consider seeking mentorship from these three... in my completely unbiased opinion ğŸ™ƒğŸ˜ğŸ¤£!

^ the best people you will ever meet

post_text:
Hi all... Talk to me about having your own office space.

I currently do social and Sensory groups for kids and I "rent out" rooms at various kid locations (about $50 for each hour of use and I do about 5-6 groups a week as of right now) 

I personally feel like this way works because I am not "tied" down to an actual monthly rent and maintenence fees. But then on the flip side, I feel like I have to ask permission for use and I'm thinking "rent" for my own space may even be less if I continue to do multiple groups a day. I see some similar businesses like mine with their own office and I wonder how they are even doing it (cost wise).

comments.text: I see kids and lease a space. I found a space that is not storefront and not â€œmedicalâ€. That helps when looking for something affordable. But I also share this space with an OT (Iâ€™m PT). So we share costs but are separate businesses.

Following.

I plan to do group meet ups once I settle in as a mobile peds PT. My initial plan is to rent spaces for the meet ups and once I have enough clients Iâ€™ll rent a space, essentially for a clinic and the social groups.

post_text:
Group Coaching is akin to you as a physical therapist taking all of your current back pain patients in a clinic, and telling them:

â€œMoving forward, all of you will be treated in a group and we will be doing the same exercises to cure your back pain.â€

If we were told to treat that way in a clinic we would argue with our superiors that our clients wouldnâ€™t get 100% better in a group scenario, but yet, we accept it for ourselves as business owners. 

I would say that 95% of business owners arenâ€™t experiencing the growth that they want in their business because of personal factors rather than having the right tactic for marketing. 

Those personal factors such as imposter syndrome, self-esteem, fear, a spouse not supporting the business, anxiety, ego, etc etc are the major road blocks to substantial and SUSTAINABLE success in business.

You need a personal mentor to coach you through that. 

Just like you would be appalled to treat back pain patients in a group setting in the above scenarioâ€¦

I am also appalled at the amount of people who simply accept this as â€œgood enoughâ€ as they strive to become the best business owner they can be. 

I donâ€™t want 80% better for you. I want you to become the best business owner that you can be so that you can radically transform your life AND the lives of your clients. 

This takes personal one-on-one attention and deep work.

post_text: Hi out there! I've been absent from this group but ready to come back. I moved from CA to PA in Sept and upended my life in so many ways. I decided to open my own mobile PT practice and also focus on writing and art. Well, after what I felt was a lot of outreach and networking and advertising locally I've only gotten one patient. Now I see her 2-3 x most weeks so she's a great patient to have! I think the universe knew I wanted to focus on my writing and I really haven't put any energy into the business but am ready to try again. I am a little discouraged however. I put a lot of time into an online free balance class I thought would be a good entry into my business with no success. I became a Medicare Part B provider even though I don't want to deal with insurance, would really like to be cash based, because I'm trying to focus on fall prevention and promoting independence in the elderly and figured I should do it. Any words of wisdom or suggestions out there? I'm not all that comfortable in front of groups so hesitate to do a class or presentation in front of a large group...plus fall prevention in a group...can't really have them do too much without huge liability issues...though I am prepared to do something if I need to. Guess I'm just looking for any words of wisdom, advice, or encouragement any of you who have read this far can offer. Thanks!

comments.text: Let's schedule a chat...
where in PA?

post_text:
We just got back from rafting the Grand Canyon and I had one of the most resonating experiences I've had in a very long time. Spilling my guts here but I think this group will appreciate the sentiment as well as anyone. 

When I was in college, I had the amazing fortune of working as a river guide for 5 years on the Colorado River, mostly in the Grand Canyon. That job prepared me for working as a PT and especially as a small business owner better than almost any other life experience. 

Rafting the Grand Canyon requires traversing a nearly 300 mile long stretch of river that includes some of the biggest whitewater in North America. We use these huge 37 foot, 4 ton, motorized rafts that can carry up to 20 people at a time. 

I applied for my permit to do this in 1997(!), which was the last year I guided and when I was first starting PT school. It's safe to say that I was going into this a bit rusty because there I was, 25 years later, piloting one of those huge motorized rafts, carrying 16 of my family and friends for 10 days, through historically low water.

As intimidated as I was going into this, one of the best things was how awesome it was to  F E E L the Support and Camaraderie from the other boaters down there, both private and commercial. Mistakes are going to happen and we need each other. Everyone has to camp somewhere at night and we have to unofficially coordinate who is staying where. 

The private trips were smaller and scattered around, most of them hadn't really done it before. The big commercial outfitters were pushing through with their huge groups, either in their motor rigs or with groups of up to 6 smaller rafts. But everyone is a part of the community. Everyone has to work together.

That feeling of support and camaraderie I felt in the Grand Canyon is extremely similar to what I feel in this user group. 
It's the feeling I get when I work with other practice owners who are trying to make their way. 
It's the feeling I get when I volunteer with the Private Practice Section of the APTA. 
And it's the feeling I get when I volunteer for our Home Health and Hospice Association or our local Climbing Advocacy Group.

With so many people running through the Grand Canyon at any given time, things could be a lot more competitive. Fortunately, it was absolutely refreshing and impressive to be a part of a community in which the guides and boatmen from each company and private trip work together to look out for each other. This was true for helping each other through the low water runs as well as for coordinating who was camping where each night.

I'd never seen water that low. Somehow, at every turn, another boatman had my back. This stuff is not easy. 
It's very technical. 
Sometimes it's extremely hot. 
Sometimes there are storms that bring thundering flash floods. 
Sometimes other people get stuck on the rocks and we have to help pull them off.

All of that feels extremely similar when I have random employment questions or regulatory or billing questions. The other 'guides' on our trip are incredibly positive as they rally with each other so we all get down safely.

There is an amazing community experience down in the Grand Canyon! There are also amazing communities here in Uncaged, with the Private Practice Section and with the other associations we have out there.  

Thanks to everyone for looking out for each other! What a cool thing to be a part of!

post_text:
**Want to know** **when I *REALLY* started loving what I do?**

I have always loved being a therapist.  I seriously don't think that there is anything else that I would do.

Yes, I experienced burnout and all of that other stuff that perhaps many of you have experienced, or are experiencing now.

When I started my own practice in 2013, I finally felt free.

But do you want to know what changed everything for me?

Want to know how I managed to get to where I am today?

Simple, really.

I did two things.

I started investing in myself with coaching.

I started attending LIVE events.  

Not your typical national association conferences.  But true LIVE events- the kind where everyone there was hungry for something different.

Everyone there knew that the status quo just wasn't going to cut it; nor was it going to take them to where they wanted to go.

The energy and momentum that came from those events were immense.

But that's not all that I got from these LIVE events.

Perhaps the greatest gift and value that I received - which skyrocketed me - was the COMMUNITY that was created at each event.

Better yet, it was the FAMILY that bonded us all.

Many stressors that I had suddenly went away, because I had found a family that had my back.  

One with whom we shared ideas - none of which were bad ideas. 

We supported each other.  We encouraged each other.  

Everyone inspired by everyone else.

It was from the same coaching program and LIVE events where I was blessed to have crossed paths with Josh Payne and Kevin DeGroot, both who are now my business partners.

I would venture to say that each of them would credit the investments that they made - and that we have made together - as keys to their successes.

And now, we want nothing more than for YOU to join us in experiencing *community*.

*And to find your family.*

We invite you to commune with us this **Oct 6-9 in Denver, CO**. for the 2nd annual UNCAGEDLIVE22

This event is for PT's, OT's, respective assistants, Chiros, SLP's, LMT's, and more.

To learn more about **UNCAGEDLIVE**, click on the link in the comments below!

We already have more than 100 family members attending!  We want you to come with us!

(Oh, and in case you're wondering.  We have coaching programs for the new and existing practice owners.  We would love to talk to you about them!)

comments.text: So pumped for this event, and the community that is being built!  #uncaged #uncagedlive2022 #community
Donâ€™t miss out on this one

post_text: just a thought to facilitate discussion: do you think the increase in therapists becoming uncaged will effect larger therapy companies ? After doing this I don't know if I ever have a desire to work for another company again (as a therapist)

comments.text:
Great question!
I can tell you that one of our missions with UNCAGED - especially through our coaching programs - is to change healthcare!
I so hope so! I encourage and mentor younger therapists to start a side gig of private clients. No more prostituting therapists! We need to take our power back!

post_text: For those of you who have a brick and mortar, how do you play music? Did you purchase a separate Spotify/Apple/etc account to play all day? I'm currently streaming music off my personal phone but wanted an option for my staff to use when I'm not there ğŸ˜‹

comments.text: One person office here, stream from the Echo (Amazon music) and ask patients what artist/genre they like vs no music or radio or podcast.

A separate business Spotify account. It runs through our Roku TV speakers that we useï¿¼ in our gym.  We did have Alexa last Here, but with Spotify we were able to make a bunch of different playlists based on what the different age groups like who come to us, and then also use it for some of our group classes.

full_thread_text:
POST: For those of you who have a brick and mortar, how do you play music? Did you purchase a separate Spotify/Apple/etc account to play all day? I'm currently streaming music off my personal phone but wanted an option for my staff to use when I'm not there ğŸ˜‹

COMMENT 1: One person office here, stream from the Echo (Amazon music) and ask patients what artist/genre they like vs no music or radio or podcast.

COMMENT 2: A separate business Spotify account. It runs through our Roku TV speakers that we useï¿¼ in our gym.  We did have Alexa last Here, but with Spotify we were able to make a bunch of different playlists based on what the different age groups like who come to us, and then also use it for some of our group classes.

post_text: What are everyone's thoughts on being an APTA member? Worth the cost?

comments.text: Iâ€™m a member.  We have no better option for power on Capitol Hill!  If we lose that, our profession heads in a very bad direction (or continues to).  If we had even half-way decent membership % we could push for some real change and reimbursement.  If not, we can probably just keep watching reimbursements fall ğŸ¤·ğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸

We have 100,000 members but there are 500,000 PTs and PTAs in the US. Membership makes the APTA stronger. Without membership we lose our collective voice. We need advocacy for our profession. Become a member, attend local chapter meetings, or join the board of your local chapter. As a member and board member, I recognize many benefits: connections/networking, professional development opportunities, continuing ed, online resources, and reduced rates for conferences to name a few.

full_thread_text:
POST: What are everyone's thoughts on being an APTA member? Worth the cost?

COMMENT 1: Iâ€™m a member.  We have no better option for power on Capitol Hill!  If we lose that, our profession heads in a very bad direction (or continues to).  If we had even half-way decent membership % we could push for some real change and reimbursement.  If not, we can probably just keep watching reimbursements fall ğŸ¤·ğŸ»â€â™‚ï¸

COMMENT 2: We have 100,000 members but there are 500,000 PTs and PTAs in the US. Membership makes the APTA stronger. Without membership we lose our collective voice. We need advocacy for our profession. Become a member, attend local chapter meetings, or join the board of your local chapter. As a member and board member, I recognize many benefits: connections/networking, professional development opportunities, continuing ed, online resources, and reduced rates for conferences to name a few.
